definition: The quality of being physically beautiful or attractive (specifically about physical appearance)
etymology: From Latin pulchritudo, from pulcher ‘beautiful’.
example: The pulchritude of the landscape left us speechless.

definition: Showing strong resistance to authority or conventional behavior
etymology: From Latin recalcitrant-, ‘kicking out with the heels’.
example: The recalcitrant student refused to comply with the rules.

definition: Ridiculously old-fashioned; of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood.
definition_2: So old or old-fashioned as to appear to belong to a former age
etymology: From Latin ante ‘before’ + diluvium ‘flood’.
example: He still uses antediluvian methods in his research.

definition: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
etymology: From Latin obsequiosus, from obsequium ‘compliance’.
example: The waiter's obsequious manner was a bit much for the guests.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
definition_2: Impervious to persuasion, especially to moral persuasion
etymology: From Latin obduratus, past participle of obdurare ‘harden’.
example: He remained obdurate, refusing to alter his decision.

definition: A ready insight into and understanding of things.
etymology: From Latin perspicax, perspicac- ‘seeing clearly’.
example: Her perspicacious mind quickly grasped the complexities of the problem.

definition: Chronically lacking in money; habitually without funds
etymology: From Latin impecuniosus, from in- ‘not’ + pecunia ‘money’.
example: He was a gifted but impecunious painter.

definition: (Of a person) excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily.
definition_2: Having a greasy or soapy feel (when referring to substances)
etymology: From late Latin unctuosus, from unctus ‘anointing’.
example: He seemed unctuous and insincere.

definition: Skillful use of one's hands when performing conjuring tricks.
definition_2: Clever trickery or deceptive maneuvering in politics or business
etymology: From French léger de main ‘light of hand’.
example: The magician's legerdemain amazed the audience.

definition: An irresolvable internal contradiction or logical disjunction in a text, argument, or theory
etymology: From Greek aporia "difficulty, perplexity", from aporos "impassable", from a- "without" + poros "passage".

definition: spiteful, bad-tempered
definition_2: Affected by or associated with nausea or vomiting
etymology: From Latin biliosus, from bilis "bile". Originally referred to an excess of bile, thought to cause irritability.

definition: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
definition_2: Characterized by excessive or exaggerated sadness
etymology: From Latin lugubris "mournful", from lugere "to mourn".

definition: A regional dialect of a language; jargon or cant.
definition_2: The specialized vocabulary of a particular profession or group
etymology: From French, literally "rough speech", from Old French patoier "to handle clumsily", from pate "paw".

definition: Harshness of tone or manner; severity of character or attitude.
definition_2: Roughness of manner; harshness of temper
etymology: From Latin asperitas, from asper "rough".

definition: Omit (a sound or syllable) when speaking; join together; merge.
definition_2: To omit or strike out (a sound or syllable) in pronunciation
etymology: From Latin elidere "to strike out", from e- "out" + laedere "to strike".

definition: (of a subject or knowledge) little known
etymology: From Latin reconditus "hidden, concealed", past participle of recondere, from re- "back" + condere "to put together".

definition: kind and friendly toward a younger or less experienced person.
etymology: From Latin avunculus "maternal uncle", diminutive of avus "grandfather".

definition: Showing great care, attention, and effort.
etymology: From Latin assiduus "constant", from assidere "to sit down to", from ad- "to" + sedere "to sit".

definition: Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
etymology: From Latin pugnax, pugnac- "combative", from pugnare "to fight".

definition: Childishly silly and trivial.
etymology: From Latin puerilis, from puer "child".

definition: A monarch or ruler, especially an autocratic one.
etymology: From late Latin potentatus "political power", from Latin potens, potent- "powerful".

definition: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
etymology: From Latin inchoatus, past participle of inchoare "to begin".

definition: Extremely bad or unpleasant.
etymology: From Latin execrabilis, from execrari "to curse", from ex- "out" + sacrare "to consecrate".

definition: (Especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.
etymology: From medieval Latin diaphanus, from Greek diaphanēs "transparent", from dia "through" + phainein "to show".

definition: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
etymology: From Latin indolent-, from in- "not" + dolere "suffer pain".

definition: Having or conveying undue or inappropriate interest in sexual matters.
etymology: From Latin salax, salac- "lustful", from salire "to leap".

definition: Lower one's body briefly by bending one knee to the ground, typically in worship or as a sign of respect; show deference or servility.
etymology: From Latin genuflectere, from genu "knee" + flectere "to bend".

definition: Tearful or given to weeping; inducing tears.
etymology: From Latin lacrimosus, from lacrima "tear".

definition: Persuade (someone) to do something by means of deception or flattery.
etymology: From French aveugler "to blind", from Old French, from a- (from Latin ad- "to") + aveugle "blind".

definition: The action of staying away from school without good reason; absenteeism.
etymology: From truant, from Old French truant "beggar, rogue", probably from Celtic.

definition: An unfilled space or interval; a gap; a missing portion in a book or manuscript.
etymology: From Latin lacuna "pool, gap", from lacus "pool".

definition: A boxer, especially a professional one.
etymology: From Latin pugil "boxer", related to pugnus "fist".

definition: A manuscript or piece of writing material on which the original writing has been effaced to make room for later writing but of which traces remain.
etymology: From Greek palimpsēstos, from palin "again" + psēstos "rubbed smooth".

definition: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes; a formal curse by a pope or a council of the Church, excommunicating a person or denouncing a doctrine.
etymology: From Greek anathema "a thing devoted", in later Greek "a thing accursed".

definition: Having a limited or narrow outlook or scope; relating to a church parish.
etymology: From Late Latin parochialis, from parochia "parish", from Greek paroikia "dwelling beside or near".

definition: Coming from outside; not native; associated by chance rather than design.
etymology: From Latin adventicius "coming from abroad", from adventus, past participle of advenire "to come to".

definition: A state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy.
etymology: From Latin lassitudo, from lassus "tired".

definition: Pregnant; full of meaning or a specified quality.
etymology: From Latin gravidus "pregnant", from gravis "heavy".

definition: Occurring or existing before a particular war, especially the American Civil War.
etymology: From Latin ante "before" + bellum "war".

definition: (Of the voice or speech) full, round, and imposing; pompous.
etymology: From Latin ore rotundo "with round mouth", from os, or- "mouth" + rotundus "round".

definition: Excessive confidence or boldness; audacity.
etymology: From Latin temeritas, from temere "rashly".

definition: Insisting on immediate attention or obedience, especially in a brusquely imperious way.
etymology: From Latin peremptorius "deadly, decisive", from perempt- "destroyed", from the verb perimere, from per- "completely" + emere "take, buy".

definition: Grimly mocking or cynical.
etymology: From French sardonique, from Latin sardonius, from Greek sardonios, possibly from a plant from Sardinia which was said to produce facial convulsions resembling a grin.

definition: Sedate, respectable, and unadventurous.
etymology: Past participle of archaic stay "to support", from Middle English steyen, from Old French estayer, from estaye "a prop".

definition: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper; happy or joyous.
etymology: From Old English bliþe "joyful, kind, gentle, pleasant", of Germanic origin.

definition: A person who is hostile or indifferent to culture and the arts, or who has no understanding of them.
etymology: From Philistine, a member of an ancient people of southern Palestine, regarded in the Bible as hostile to the Israelites.

definition: A state of eternal punishment and damnation into which a sinful and unpenitent person passes after death.
etymology: From Latin perditio(n-), from perdere "to destroy", from per- "completely" + dare "to give".

definition: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt.
etymology: From Latin contritus "worn out, ground down", from the verb conterere, from con- "together" + terere "to rub".

definition: Avoidance of activity or exertion; laziness.
etymology: From Latin indolentia "freedom from pain", from in- "not" + dolere "suffer pain".

definition: Behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others.
etymology: From Latin superciliosus "haughty", from supercilium "eyebrow" (as raised in arrogance).

definition: Showing or motivated by susceptibility to bribery; corrupt.
etymology: From Latin venalis "for sale", from venum "sale".

definition: having or encouraging an excessive interest in sexual matters, especially the sexual activity of others
etymology: From Latin prurient- "itching, longing", from the verb prurire.

definition: an image or representation of someone or something
etymology: From Latin simulacrum "likeness, image", from simulare "to copy, represent".

definition: glowing, gleaming or flickering with a soft radiance
etymology: From Latin lambent-’licking’, from the verb lambere

definition: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating or drinking
etymology: From Latin abstemius, from ab- "away from" + stem of temetum "intoxicating drink".

definition: Not telling the truth; lying.
definition_2: Given to or characterized by lying
etymology: From Latin mendax, mendac- ‘lying’.
example: Mendacious politicians are nothing new.

definition: Excessively theatrical or dramatic in character or style.
definition_2: Deliberately affected or theatrical
etymology: From Latin histrionicus ‘pertaining to actors’.
example: His histrionic outburst shocked everyone.

definition: Cheerful and full of energy.
definition_2: Bubbling with enthusiasm or excitement
etymology: From Latin ebullient-, from ebullire ‘bubble out’.
example: She was ebullient about her new job.

definition: Silly and pointless.
definition_2: Foolishly vacant or stupid
etymology: From Latin fatuus ‘foolish’.
example: Don't badger people with fatuous questions.

definition: A flattering or pleasing statement or action used to persuade someone gently to do something.
definition_2: Speech or action that flatters and tends to coax
etymology: From French blandissement, from blandir ‘to flatter’.
example: She used every blandishment to get her way.

definition: To repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
definition_2: To abolish by authoritative action
etymology: From Latin abrogat-, from abrogare ‘repeal’.
example: The treaty was abrogated in 1929.

definition: Destiny; fate.
etymology: From Turkish, from Arabic qisma ‘division, portion, fate’.
example: It was kismet that they met that day.

definition: The appearance of being true or real.
etymology: From Latin verisimilitudo, from verus ‘true’ + similis ‘like’.
example: The novel's verisimilitude made the story all the more compelling.

definition: Noisy and difficult to control.
etymology: From Latin obstreperus, from ob- ‘against’ + strepere ‘make a noise’.
example: The obstreperous crowd refused to settle down despite repeated warnings.

definition: Using very few words.
etymology: From Greek Lakōnikos, referring to the Spartans, who were known for their terse speech.
example: Her laconic reply left everyone in the room puzzled.

definition: (Of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.
etymology: From Latin cogent-, from cogere ‘drive together’.
example: She presented a cogent argument for the new policy.

definition: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style.
etymology: From Old French trenchant, from trencher ‘to cut’.
example: His trenchant remarks cut through the confusion.

definition: Divide into two branches or forks.
etymology: From late Latin bifurcatus, past participle of bifurcare, from bi- "two" + furca "fork".

definition: Conceal or disguise one's true feelings or beliefs.
etymology: From Latin dissimulare "to disguise or conceal", from dis- "apart" + simulare "to copy, represent".

definition: The quality of being pleasantly stimulating or exciting.
etymology: From French piquant "pricking", present participle of piquer "to prick".

definition: An organized whole that is perceived as more than the sum of its parts.
etymology: From German Gestalt "shape, form".

definition: Exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
definition_2: Caught up in the romance of noble deeds and the pursuit of unreachable goals
etymology: From Don Quixote, the hero of a romance by Cervantes, noted for his idealism and chivalrous but impractical behavior.
example: His plans to build a utopia were as quixotic as they were ambitious.

definition: Restrict (something) within limits.
definition_2: To draw a line around; to encircle completely
etymology: From Latin circumscribere, from circum ‘around’ + scribere ‘write’.
example: The rules circumscribe the powers of the committee.

definition: Lasting for a very short time.
definition_2: Lasting only one day (especially of insects or flowers)
etymology: From Greek ephēmeros ‘lasting only a day’.
example: Fame in the world of pop music can be ephemeral.

definition: To render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
definition_2: To make so confused or opaque as to be difficult to perceive or understand
etymology: From Latin obfuscat-, ‘darkened’, from the verb obfuscare.
example: The report was written in a way that would obfuscate the real issues.

definition: Having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment; wise or shrewd.
definition_2: Having or showing acute mental discernment and keen practical sense
etymology: From Latin sagax, sagac- ‘wise’.
example: The sagacious leader guided the country through difficult times.

definition: (Of a voice or words) sweet or musical; pleasant to hear.
definition_2: Having a smooth rich flow (especially of sound)
etymology: From Latin mellifluus, from mel ‘honey’ + fluere ‘to flow’.
example: She spoke in a mellifluous voice that captivated the audience.

definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
definition_2: Too sacred to be uttered; forbidden to be spoken
etymology: From Latin ineffabilis, from in- ‘not’ + effabilis ‘able to be expressed’.
example: The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
definition_2: A drug or other substance that induces sleep
etymology: From French soporifique, from Latin sopor ‘sleep’.
example: The professor's soporific lecture made it hard to stay awake.

definition: Vehement or clamorous.
definition_2: Expressing feelings or opinions in a very loud or forceful way
etymology: From Latin vociferari, from vox ‘voice’ + ferre ‘carry’.
example: The vociferous crowd cheered for their team.

definition: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
definition_2: The quality of being calm and even-tempered
etymology: From Latin aequanimitas, from aequus ‘equal’ + animus ‘mind’.
example: She accepted the bad news with remarkable equanimity.

definition: A person who acts obsequiously toward someone important in order to gain advantage.
definition_2: One who attempts to win favor by flattering influential people
etymology: From Greek sukophantes, originally ‘informer’.
example: The office sycophant was always flattering the boss.

definition: Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
definition_2: Temperamentally disinclined to talk
etymology: From Latin taciturnus, from tacere ‘be silent’.
example: He was a taciturn man, but his actions spoke volumes.

definition: A state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.
definition_2: A puzzling predicament
etymology: Origin unknown, first recorded in the late 16th century.
example: She was in a quandary about whether to accept the offer.

definition: To cause (someone) to feel drained of energy; weaken.
etymology: From Latin enervatus, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of’ + nervus ‘sinew’.
example: The hot sun enervated her to the point of collapse.

definition: Unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
etymology: From French intransigeant, from Spanish intransigente.
example: The negotiations broke down due to both sides being intransigent.

definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
etymology: From modern Latin ubiquitas, from Latin ubique ‘everywhere’.
example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

definition: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.
definition_2: A difficulty or hardship attendant on a way of life or career
etymology: From Latin vicissitudo, from vicissim ‘by turns’.
example: He endured the vicissitudes of a turbulent career.

definition: A soft gentle breeze.
definition_2: A lightweight fabric or garment
etymology: From Greek Zephuros, god of the west wind.
example: A zephyr cooled the hot summer air.

definition: (Of a story or statement) of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.
definition_2: Being of questionable authenticity
etymology: From Greek apokruphos ‘hidden’.
example: The story of the haunted house is probably apocryphal.

definition: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices rather than by using rational argument.
definition_2: A leader who makes use of popular prejudices and false claims and promises
etymology: From Greek dēmagōgos, from dēmos ‘people’ + agōgos ‘leading’.
example: The demagogue stirred up the crowd with fiery rhetoric.

definition: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
definition_2: Reflecting a meticulous, sensitive, or demanding nature
etymology: From Latin fastidiosus, from fastidium ‘loathing’.
example: He chooses his words with fastidious care.

definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
definition_2: Given to excessive and often trivial or rambling talk
etymology: From Latin garrulus, from garrire ‘to chatter’.
example: The garrulous host kept the guests entertained all night.

definition: A lengthy and aggressive speech.
definition_2: To deliver a pompous or aggressive speech
etymology: From Italian aringa, from aringare ‘to speak in public’.
example: He delivered a harangue about the evils of the media.

definition: A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
definition_2: One who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
etymology: From Greek eikonoklastēs, from eikōn ‘image’ + klan ‘to break’.
example: The artist was known as an iconoclast in the art world.

definition: To place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
etymology: From French juxtaposer, from Latin juxta ‘next’ + French poser ‘to place’.
example: The exhibition juxtaposes modern art with classical sculpture.

definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
definition_2: Having full use of ones mental faculties; sane
etymology: From Latin lucidus, from lucere ‘shine’.
example: She gave a lucid account of the events.

definition: (Typically of an action or activity) wicked or criminal.
definition_2: Utterly wicked or evil
etymology: From Latin nefarius, from nefas ‘wrong, crime’.
example: The nefarious activities of the organized-crime syndicates were widely reported.

definition: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
definition_2: A perfect diamond of 100 carats or more
etymology: From Old French paragon, from Italian paragone ‘touchstone’.
example: She is a paragon of virtue.

definition: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
definition_2: Deep-seated ill will or hatred
etymology: From Latin rancor ‘rankness’.
example: She answered her accusers calmly and without rancor.

definition: Equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as.
etymology: From Italian tanto ‘so much’ + ammontare ‘to amount to’.
example: His silence was tantamount to an admission of guilt.

definition: To employ endearments or flattery to persuade someone to do something or give one something.
etymology: Of uncertain origin, perhaps from Old English.
example: She managed to wheedle another piece of cake from her mother.

definition: An uneducated and unsophisticated person from the countryside.
etymology: Of unknown origin, first recorded in the 19th century.
example: The city folk looked down on the yokel.

definition: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
definition_2: One who is zealous on behalf of a cause
etymology: From Greek zēlōtēs, from zēlos ‘zeal’.
example: He was a zealot for environmental causes.

definition: Cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender.
etymology: From Latin capitulatus, from capitulum ‘chapter, heading’.
example: The enemy was forced to capitulate unconditionally.

definition: Causing harm or damage.
etymology: From Greek dēlētērios ‘noxious’.
example: Divorce is assumed to have deleterious effects on children.

definition: Insolent or impertinent behavior.
etymology: From French effronterie, from effronté ‘shameless’.
example: He had the effrontery to challenge the decision.

definition: (Especially of a person) unfortunate.
definition_2: Having no luck; unfortunate
etymology: From Old Norse happ ‘good luck’.
example: The hapless passengers were stranded at the airport.

definition: A constantly changing pattern or sequence of objects or elements.
definition_2: A succession of changing phases or actions
etymology: From Greek kalos ‘beautiful’ + eidos ‘form’ + skopein ‘to look at’.
example: The city lights formed a kaleidoscope of colors.

definition: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
definition_2: A person who hates or distrusts humankind
etymology: From Greek misanthrōpos, from misein ‘to hate’ + anthrōpos ‘man’.
example: The old man was a misanthrope who lived alone.

definition: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief.
definition_2: A person newly converted to a belief
etymology: From Greek neophutos ‘newly planted’.
example: As a neophyte, she still had much to learn.

definition: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
definition_2: A remedy for all ills or difficulties
etymology: From Greek panakeia, from pan ‘all’ + akos ‘remedy’.
example: There is no single panacea for the world's economic problems.

definition: A strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something.
definition_2: A strong and continued inclination
etymology: From French penchant ‘leaning’.
example: She has a penchant for chocolate.

definition: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner.
definition_2: Given to complaining; peevish
etymology: From Latin querulus, from queri ‘to complain’.
example: The querulous old woman was never satisfied.

definition: A person who tells anecdotes in a skillful and amusing way.
definition_2: A person skilled in telling stories
etymology: From French.
example: She was a brilliant raconteur.

definition: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.
definition_2: Kept secret, especially for improper purposes
etymology: From Latin surreptitius, from surripere ‘seize secretly’.
example: They carried on a surreptitious affair.

definition: Very weak or slight.
definition_2: Having little substance or strength
etymology: From Latin tenuis ‘thin’.
example: The link between them was tenuous.

definition: Attractive or appealing in appearance or character.
definition_2: Fresh and innocently charming
etymology: From Old English wynsum, from wynn ‘joy’.
example: She had a winsome smile.

definition: Refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
etymology: From Greek adamas ‘untameable’.
example: He is adamant that he is not going to resign.

definition: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
etymology: From Middle French bombaste ‘cotton padding’.
example: His bombastic rhetoric concealed his lack of ideas.

definition: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
etymology: From Greek kakophōnia, from kakos ‘bad’ + phōnē ‘voice’.
example: A cacophony of car horns filled the air.

definition: Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
etymology: From Greek didaktikos, from didaskein ‘to teach’.
example: The novel had a didactic purpose.

definition: (Of a person) fond of company; sociable.
etymology: From Latin gregarius, from grex ‘flock’.
example: He was a popular and gregarious man.

definition: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
etymology: From Latin ignominiosus, from ignominia ‘disgrace’.
example: It was an ignominious end to his career.

definition: Stated or appearing to be true, but not necessarily so.
etymology: From French ostensible, from Latin ostendere ‘to show’.
example: The ostensible reason for his visit was to see his parents.

definition: (Of a feeling or atmosphere) so intense as to seem almost tangible.
etymology: From late Latin palpabilis, from palpare ‘to feel’.
example: There was a palpable sense of relief in the room.

definition: In a state or period of inactivity or dormancy.
etymology: From Latin quiescent-, from quiescere ‘be quiet’.
example: The volcano had been quiescent for centuries.

definition: Strongly reminiscent or suggestive of (something).
etymology: From Latin redolent-, from redolere ‘emit a scent’.
example: The air was redolent of pine needles.

definition: Slow and gloomy.
etymology: From Latin saturninus ‘of Saturn’.
example: His saturnine disposition made him difficult to befriend.

definition: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
etymology: From Latin truculentus, from trux ‘fierce’.
example: His truculent attitude alienated many people.

definition: Offense or annoyance.
etymology: From French ombrage ‘shade’.
example: She took umbrage at his remarks.

definition: Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
etymology: From Latin vacillat-, from vacillare ‘sway to and fro’.
example: She vacillated between the two options.

definition: Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.
etymology: From wistly ‘attentively’.
example: She cast a wistful glance at the departing train.

definition: Think deeply about something, meditate or reflect
etymology: From Latin cogitatus, past participle of cogitare "to think", from co- "together" + agitare "to turn over, consider".

definition: a pithy observation that contains a general truth, such as, “if it ain't broke, don't fix it.”.
etymology: From Greek aphorismos "definition, pithy sentence", from aphorizein "to mark off, divide".

definition: make someone less angry or hostile
etymology: From Latin placatus, past participle of placare "to calm, appease".

definition: Tending to obstruct or harm; unfriendly; hostile.
etymology: From Latin inimicalis, from inimicus "enemy", from in- "not" + amicus "friend".

definition: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered, very irritable
etymology: From Latin irascibilis, from irasci "to be angry", from ira "anger".

definition: having a strong religious or spiritual quality; indicating or suggesting the presence of a divinity
etymology: From Latin numinosus, from numen "divine power".

definition: not straightforward, indirect
etymology: From Latin obliquus "slanting, sidelong, indirect".

definition: Excessively concerned with minor details and rules or with displaying academic learning
etymology: From French pédantique, from Italian pedante "teacher, schoolmaster".

definition: Reluctant to share ones thoughts and feelings
etymology: From Latin reticent- "remaining silent", from the verb reticere, from re- (expressing intensive force) + tacere "be silent".

definition: producing good effects; beneficial,(especially with reference to something unwelcome
etymology: From Latin salutaris "health-giving", from salus, salut- "health".

definition: The meaning of a word, phrase, sentence or text
etymology: From French sémantique, from Greek sēmantikos "significant", from sēmainein "to show, signify", from sēma "sign".

definition: causing or tending to cause annoyance, frustration, or worry.
etymology: From Latin vexare "to shake, disturb, harass".

definition: in a way that is experienced in the imagination through the actions of another person.
etymology: From Latin vicarius "substitute", from vicis "change, alternation".

definition: a change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome
definition_2: A difficulty or hardship attendant on a way of life or career
etymology: From Latin vicissitudo, from vicissim "by turns", from vicis "change".

definition: overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style
definition_2: Deliberately affected or theatrical
etymology: From Latin histrionicus "pertaining to an actor", from histrio "actor".

definition: (especially of a comment or style of speaking) sharp and forthright
etymology: From Latin acerbus "bitter, harsh, sour", from acer "sharp".

definition: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight
etymology: From Latin bellicosus, from bellicus "of war", from bellum "war".

definition: Relating to or characterized by reversion to something ancient or ancestral
etymology: From Latin atavus "ancestor", from at- (beyond) + avus "grandfather".

definition: leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
etymology: From Greek hegemonia "leadership, rule", from hegemon "leader".

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion
definition_2: Impervious to persuasion, especially to moral persuasion
etymology: From Latin obduratus "hardened", past participle of obdurare "to harden".

definition: Deceitful and untrustworthy
etymology: From Latin perfidiosus, from perfidia "treachery", from perfidus "faithless", from per- "through" + fides "faith".

definition: depravity; wickedness
etymology: From Latin turpitudo "baseness", from turpis "vile, base, shameful".

definition: having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change
etymology: From Latin inveteratus "of long standing", past participle of inveterare "to make old", from in- "in" + vetus "old".

definition: generally considered or reputed to be
etymology: From Latin putativus, from putare "to consider, suppose".

definition: pleasure derived by someone from another person's misfortune.
etymology: From German Schadenfreude, from Schaden "harm" + Freude "joy".

definition: an elaborate or complicated procedure
etymology: Alteration of ragman roll, a document with many seals, later used for a long list or catalog.

definition: highly complex or intricate and occasionally devious
etymology: From Byzantine, relating to Byzantium (Constantinople), known for complex administration and intrigue.

definition: belonging to a period other than that being portrayed
etymology: From Greek anakhronismos, from ana- "against" + khronos "time".

definition: a person opposed to new technology or ways of working
etymology: From the Luddites, 19th-century English workers who destroyed machinery that threatened their jobs.

definition: a clever but false argument, especially one used deliberately to deceive
etymology: late Middle English, from Old French sophime, via Latin from Greek sophisma ‘clever device’

definition: annoyance or distress at having failed or been humiliated
etymology: From French chagrin "melancholy, anxiety", possibly from Old French graigne "sadness".

definition: adorn with chains, garlands, or other decorations
etymology: From French feston, from Italian festone "a festoon", from festa "feast".

definition: swollen and distended or congested
etymology: From Latin turgidus "swollen", from turgere "to swell".

definition: Extreme poverty; destitution.
etymology: From Latin penuria "want, need, scarcity".

definition: Expressing contempt or disapproval.
etymology: From French péjoratif, from Latin pejorare "to make worse", from pejor "worse".

definition: Care or concern for someone or something.
etymology: From Latin sollicitudo, from sollicitus "anxious", from sollus "entire" + citus "aroused".

definition: Friendly, lively, and enjoyable; (of a person) cheerful and friendly; jovial.
etymology: From Latin convivialis, from convivium "a feast", from con- "with" + vivere "to live".

definition: Warn or reprimand someone firmly.
etymology: From Latin admonere "to remind, warn", from ad- "to" + monere "warn".

definition: lacking foresight or intellectual insight
etymology: From Greek myōpia, from myōps "short-sighted", from myein "to shut" + ōps "eye".

definition: Outstandingly bad; shocking.
etymology: From Latin egregius "outstanding", from e- "out of" + grex, greg- "flock".

definition: A person who cultivates an area of interest without real commitment or knowledge.
etymology: From Italian dilettante "lover of the arts", from dilettare "to delight", from Latin delectare.

definition: A person displaying aggressive or exaggerated patriotism; a person displaying excessive or prejudiced support for their own cause or group.
etymology: From French chauvinisme, named after Nicolas Chauvin, a legendary French soldier and patriot.

definition: Extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy.
etymology: From jingo, a word used in a popular song supporting British policy during the Russo-Turkish War (1877–78).

definition: Having the style or diction of prose; lacking poetic beauty; commonplace; unromantic.
etymology: From Latin prosaicus, from prosa "prose".

definition: The elevation of someone to divine status; the highest point in the development of something; culmination or climax.
etymology: From Greek apotheōsis "deification", from apotheoun "deify", from apo- "completely" + theos "god".

definition: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
etymology: From Latin ambi- "both" + valentia "strength", from valere "be strong".

definition: Charming or enchanting, often in a deceptive way.
etymology: From Middle Dutch begīlen "to deceive".

definition: A thick, sticky dark syrup made from partly refined sugar; cloying sentimentality or flattery.
etymology: From Middle English triacle "antidote", via Old French from Latin theriaca, from Greek thēriakē "antidote against a poisonous bite".

definition: Relating to tailoring, clothes, or style of dress.
etymology: From Latin sartor "tailor", from sarcire "to patch, mend".

definition: The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.
etymology: From Greek aigis, the shield of Zeus or Athena.

definition: Impossible to subdue or defeat.
etymology: From Latin indomitabilis, from in- "not" + domitare "to tame".

definition: The use of ambiguous language to conceal the truth or to avoid committing oneself; prevarication.
etymology: From Late Latin aequivocationem, from aequivocus "ambiguous", from aequus "equal" + vocare "to call".

definition: Patient self-control; restraint and tolerance.
etymology: From Old English forberan "to bear, endure", from for- + beran "to bear".

definition: Lacking initiative or strength of character; irresponsible.
etymology: From Scottish feck "effect, value", from Middle English fek, shortened from effect + -less.

definition: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.
etymology: From Greek esōterikos "belonging to an inner circle", from esōterō "more within", comparative of esō "within".

definition: Walk in a furtive, unobtrusive, or timid manner, especially sideways or obliquely.
etymology: From side + -le (frequentative suffix).

definition: An act of attacking or plundering.
etymology: From Latin depraedatio(n-), from the verb depraedari, from de- "completely" + praedari "plunder".

definition: Causing the contraction of body tissues, typically of the skin; severe or stern in manner.
etymology: From Latin astringent- "binding", from the verb astringere, from ad- "to" + stringere "to bind".

definition: Calm, dependable, and showing little emotion or animation.
etymology: From Latin stolidus "dull, slow".

definition: Provoke or annoy (someone) so as to stimulate some action or reaction.
etymology: From Old English gad "a spike", of Germanic origin.

definition: Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence.
etymology: From Latin diffident- "lacking confidence", from the verb diffidere, from dis- "away" + fidere "to trust".

definition: Soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
etymology: From Latin evanescent- "disappearing", from the verb evanescere, from e- "out of" + vanescere "vanish".

definition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
etymology: From French ostentatieux, from Latin ostentatio(n-) "display", from the verb ostentare, frequentative of ostendere "to show".

definition: Referring to sexual matters in an amusingly rude or irreverent way.
etymology: From Old French ribauld "rogue, rascal", from riber "to be wanton", of Germanic origin.

definition: (Of land) used or suitable for growing crops.
etymology: From Latin arabilis, from arare "to plow".

definition: Giving one's name to a person, place, or thing.
etymology: From Greek epōnumos "given as a name, giving one's name to someone or something", from epi "upon" + onoma "name".

definition: Cheat or defraud (someone).
etymology: Perhaps from Old English *bilican "to deceive", or from the card game of cribbage, where it meant "to spoil someone's score".

definition: An artistic work in a style that imitates that of another work, artist, or period.
etymology: From French, from Italian pasticcio, from pasta "paste".

definition: Impossible to understand or interpret.
etymology: From Latin inscrutabilis, from in- "not" + scrutari "to examine".

definition: The appearance of being true or real.
etymology: From Latin verisimilitudo, from verisimilis "probable", from veri (genitive of verus "true") + similis "like".

definition: Conducive to success; favorable.
etymology: From Latin auspicium "divination by observing birds", from auspex "bird seer".

definition: Relating to the River Styx; extremely dark, gloomy, or forbidding.
etymology: From Latin Stygius, from Greek Stugios, from Stux, Stug- "Styx" (a river of the underworld).

definition: The state or feeling of being actively opposed or hostile to someone or something.
etymology: From Old French enemite, from Latin inimicitas, from inimicus "enemy".

definition: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
etymology: From Greek antipatheia, from anti- "against" + pathos "feeling".

definition: Giving or indicating a good chance of success; favorable.
etymology: From Latin propitius "favorable".

definition: Showing or producing exalted joy or blessedness.
etymology: From Latin beatificus, from beatus "blessed" + -ficus "-making".

definition: A distinctive or peculiar feature or characteristic of a place or thing; a peculiarity of constitution or temperament.
etymology: From Greek idiosunkrasia, from idios "own, private" + sunkrasis "mixture, temperament".

definition: A sign or warning that something, especially something momentous or calamitous, is likely to happen.
etymology: From Latin portentum "omen, token", from portendere "to foretell".

definition: Accustom (someone) to something, especially something unpleasant.
etymology: From Middle English inure "to come into use", from in- + ure "use, practice".

definition: Poor; needy.
etymology: From Latin indigent- "lacking", from the verb indigere, from indu- "within" + egere "to need".

definition: Take (a position of power or importance) illegally or by force.
etymology: From Latin usurpare "to take possession of without legal claim".

definition: Able to perceive or feel things.
etymology: From Latin sentient- "feeling", from the verb sentire.

definition: Relating to moods, feelings, and attitudes.
etymology: From Latin affect- "influenced, affected", from the verb afficere, from ad- "to" + facere "to make".

definition: Filled or well-supplied with something.
etymology: From Latin repletus "filled up", past participle of replere, from re- "again" + plere "to fill".

definition: (Especially of a theory or argument) appearing neat and comprehensive only by ignoring the true complexities of an issue; superficial.
etymology: From Latin facilis "easy", from facere "to make".

definition: (Of air, especially that at high altitudes) of lower pressure than usual; thin; (of a subject or environment) only for or understood by a small number of people with specialized knowledge.
etymology: From Latin rarus "thin, sparse" + facere "to make".

definition: Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance; having no comforts or luxuries; harsh or ascetic.
etymology: From Latin austerus, from Greek austēros "harsh, severe".

definition: Self-confidence or assurance, especially when in a demanding situation.
etymology: From French à plomb "according to a plumb line", from à "to" + plomb "lead weight".

definition: An outcast; a person who is rejected from society or home.
etymology: From Tamil paraiyar, plural of paraiyan "drummer" (as the name of a caste of low status).

definition: Relating to the body, especially as distinct from the mind.
etymology: From Greek sōmatikos, from sōma "body".

definition: Do something that one considers to be beneath one's dignity.
etymology: From Old French deignier, from Latin dignari "to consider worthy", from dignus "worthy".

definition: All the gods of a people or religion collectively; a temple dedicated to all the gods; a group of particularly respected, famous, or important people.
etymology: From Greek pantheion "temple of all the gods", from pan "all" + theion "of the gods".

definition: Make a forcefully reproachful protest.
etymology: From medieval Latin remonstratus, past participle of remonstrare, from re- (expressing opposition) + monstrare "to show".

definition: Brisk and cheerful readiness.
etymology: From Latin alacritas, from alacer "brisk, lively".

definition: Without a clearly defined shape or form.
etymology: From Greek amorphos "shapeless", from a- "without" + morphē "form".

definition: Deprived of or lacking something, especially a non-material asset.
etymology: Past participle of bereave, from Old English bereafian, from be- + reafian "to rob, plunder".

definition: Persuade (someone) to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery.
etymology: From French cajoler, perhaps from Picard "to chatter like a jay", from gajole "cage".

definition: Jump or dance around excitedly.
etymology: Perhaps from curvet, from Italian corvetta "a leap", from Latin curvus "curved".

definition: Corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
etymology: From Latin commensuratus, from com- "together" + mensuratus "measured".

definition: A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows the doing of something bad.
etymology: From Latin compunctio(n-), from the verb compungere, from com- "together" + pungere "to prick".

definition: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
etymology: From Greek eklektikos, from eklektos "selected", from eklegein "to select", from ek "out" + legein "to choose".

definition: Threats, violence, constraints, or other action brought to bear on someone to do something against their will or better judgment.
etymology: From Old French duresse, from Latin duritia "hardness", from durus "hard".

definition: Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
etymology: From late Latin aequivocus, from aequi- "equally" + vocare "to call".

definition: Praise enthusiastically.
etymology: From Latin extollere "to raise up, elevate", from ex- "up" + tollere "to raise".

definition: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
etymology: From late Latin impetuosus, from impetus "attack".

definition: Impossible to stop or prevent.
etymology: From Latin inexorabilis, from in- "not" + exorabilis "able to be entreated", from exorare "to prevail upon".

definition: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects.
etymology: From Latin insidiosus, from insidiae "ambush", from insidere "to lie in wait for", from in- "in" + sedere "to sit".

definition: Exclude (someone) from a society or group.
etymology: From Greek ostrakizein, from ostrakon "tile, potsherd" (used as a voting tablet).

definition: Be a sign or warning of (an imminent event, typically an unwelcome one).
etymology: From Latin praesagium, from praesagire "to forebode", from prae "before" + sagire "perceive keenly".

definition: Assign an inferior rank or position to.
etymology: From Latin relegatus, past participle of relegare "to send away, banish", from re- "back" + legare "to send".

definition: Forming a very small remnant of something that was once much larger or more noticeable.
etymology: From Latin vestigium "footprint, trace".

definition: Bitter criticism or malice.
etymology: From Latin vitriolum "sulfuric acid", from vitrum "glass".

definition: Calm, peaceful, and untroubled.
etymology: From Latin serenus 'clear, unclouded.'
example: The lake was serene in the early morning.

definition: Shine brightly, especially with reflected light.
etymology: Old English glǣm 'brightness, splendor.'
example: A gleam of sunlight broke through the clouds.

definition: Amusement, especially as expressed in laughter.
etymology: Old English myrgth 'joy, pleasure.'
example: The room was filled with the mirth of children.

definition: Think about something carefully.
etymology: From Latin ponderare 'weigh, consider.'
example: He sat to ponder the meaning of life.

definition: Active, fast, and energetic.
etymology: Origin unknown, perhaps imitative.
example: She took a brisk walk in the park.

definition: Live in or at a specified place.
etymology: Old English dwellan 'lead astray, hinder.'
example: They dwell in a small cottage by the sea.

definition: Having or showing a modest or low estimate of one's importance.
etymology: From Latin humilis 'low, lowly.'
example: She remained humble despite her success.

definition: Quick and light in movement or action.
etymology: Old English nǣmel 'quick to seize.'
example: The cat was nimble as it leapt onto the wall.

definition: Collect gradually and bit by bit.
etymology: From Old French glener, from Latin glennare 'make a collection.'
example: She gleaned information from various sources.

definition: Be constantly or visibly worried or anxious.
etymology: Old English fretan 'devour.'
example: Don't fret; everything will be fine.

definition: Strongly and solidly built.
etymology: From Old French estourdi 'dazed.'
example: The sturdy table held all the dishes.

definition: Having or showing eagerness or enthusiasm.
etymology: Old English cene 'bold, brave.'
example: She has a keen interest in science.

definition: Lie exposed to warmth and light, typically from the sun.
etymology: Old Norse bask 'to bathe.'
example: The lizard basked in the sun.

definition: Attractively unusual or old-fashioned.
etymology: From Old French cointe 'clever, cunning.'
example: They stayed in a quaint little village.

definition: Remain hidden so as to wait in ambush.
etymology: Middle English lorken 'to lie hidden.'
example: The cat would lurk in the shadows.

definition: Walk or move at a slow, relaxed pace.
etymology: Old French ambler 'to walk as a horse does.'
example: They amble along the riverbank.

definition: The darker stage of twilight.
etymology: Old English dox 'dark.'
example: The streetlights flickered on at dusk.

definition: Active; lively, especially for one's age.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: The spry old man danced with the children.

definition: A short story, typically with animals as characters, conveying a moral.
etymology: From Latin fabula 'story.'
example: The tortoise and the hare is a famous fable.

definition: A place on the coast where vessels may find shelter.
etymology: Old English herebeorg 'shelter, lodging.'
example: The ship sailed into the harbor.

definition: Not active or in use.
etymology: Old English īdel 'empty, useless.'
example: The factory stood idle for months.

definition: Happy and cheerful.
etymology: From Old French jolif 'festive.'
example: He was in a jolly mood.

definition: Light or set on fire.
etymology: Old Norse kynda 'to kindle.'
example: She kindled a fire in the hearth.

definition: Full of life and energy.
etymology: Old English līflic 'living.'
example: The market was lively with activity.

definition: A piece of grassland, especially one used for hay.
etymology: Old English mǣdwe 'meadow.'
example: Cows grazed in the meadow.

definition: A conception of or belief about something.
etymology: From Latin notio 'idea.'
example: She had a notion to try skydiving.

definition: Richly luxurious and expensive.
etymology: From French peluche 'plush.'
example: They stayed in a plush hotel.

definition: Walk in a leisurely way.
etymology: Origin unknown, perhaps from German strollen 'to loaf.'
example: They strolled through the park.

definition: Make (a sound) with one's voice.
etymology: Old English utera 'outer.'
example: He uttered a sigh of relief.

definition: A sudden desire or change of mind.
etymology: Origin unknown, perhaps from whim-wham 'fanciful object.'
example: She left on a whim.

definition: A long, often elaborate narrative of real or fictitious adventures.
etymology: Old English gearn 'spun fiber.'
example: He spun a yarn about his travels.

definition: Great energy or enthusiasm.
etymology: From Greek zēlos 'ardor.'
example: She worked with great zeal.

definition: Great delight.
etymology: Old English gléo 'entertainment, music.'
example: She clapped her hands in glee.

definition: Excellent; first-rate.
etymology: Origin unknown, perhaps from French.
example: He looked dandy in his new suit.

definition: Strongly wanting to do or have something.
etymology: Old English eagor 'sharp.'
example: The children were eager for the trip.

definition: Feel a desire or liking for.
etymology: From Old French fantasie 'imagination.'
example: Do you fancy a cup of tea?

definition: A flash or beam of light.
etymology: Old English glǣm 'brightness, splendor.'
example: A gleam of hope shone in his eyes.

definition: Push or shake abruptly and roughly.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: The bus jolted to a stop.

definition: An acquired or natural skill at performing a task.
etymology: From Middle English knak 'sharp sound.'
example: She has a knack for painting.

definition: Fasten (a door or gate) with a latch.
etymology: Old English læcce 'fastening.'
example: He latched the gate behind him.

definition: Pleasingly smooth or soft; free from harshness.
etymology: From Old English melu 'meal, flour.'
example: The wine had a mellow flavor.

definition: Particularly good, skillful, or effective.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: That's a nifty gadget!

definition: Having or showing determined courage.
etymology: From pluck 'courage.'
example: The plucky puppy barked at the bigger dog.

definition: A peculiar behavioral habit.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: He has a quirk of tapping his foot.

definition: Relating to the countryside; rural.
etymology: From Latin rusticus 'of the country.'
example: They enjoyed a rustic cabin retreat.

definition: Comfortable, warm, and cozy.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: She felt snug under the blanket.

definition: Spin quickly and lightly around.
etymology: From Old French twirler 'to turn.'
example: She twirled on the dance floor.

definition: Cheerful; optimistic.
etymology: From up + beat.
example: He is always upbeat about the future.

definition: Showing or characterized by quick and inventive verbal humor.
etymology: From wit + -y.
example: She made a witty remark.

definition: At some distance in the direction indicated.
etymology: From Old English geond 'over, beyond.'
example: The mountains yonder are beautiful.

definition: Great enthusiasm and energy.
etymology: From French zeste 'orange or lemon peel.'
example: She tackled the project with zest.

definition: Produce flowers; be in flower.
etymology: Old Norse blóm 'flower.'
example: The cherry trees bloom in April.

definition: Grasp or seize (something) tightly or eagerly.
etymology: Old English clyccan 'to clench.'
example: She clutched her bag tightly.

definition: Blind (a person) temporarily.
etymology: From Old French daseler 'to daze.'
example: The bright lights dazzled the audience.

definition: Shine unsteadily; vary rapidly in brightness.
etymology: Old English flicorian 'to flutter.'
example: The candlelight flickered in the breeze.

definition: See or perceive briefly or partially.
etymology: From Middle English glimsen 'to shine faintly.'
example: She glimpsed a deer in the woods.

definition: Crowd together; nestle closely.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: The players huddled before the game.

definition: Of imposing height.
etymology: From Old Norse lopt 'air, sky.'
example: The cathedral has lofty ceilings.

definition: Say something in a low, soft, or indistinct voice.
etymology: From Latin murmurare 'to murmur.'
example: She murmured a reply.

definition: Prod (someone) gently with one's elbow.
etymology: Origin unknown.
example: He nudged me and pointed to the sign.

definition: Stare at in a lecherous manner.
etymology: From Low German oeglen 'look at.'
example: He ogles the desserts in the bakery window.

definition: Move with high springy steps.
etymology: From Middle English prauncen.
example: The horse pranced around the field.

definition: Move rapidly downward through the air.
etymology: From Middle English swopen 'to sweep.'
example: The hawk swooped down on its prey.

definition: Twist together into a confused mass.
etymology: From Old Norse tǫngull 'seaweed.'
example: The wires were tangled behind the desk.

definition: Show or guide (someone) somewhere.
etymology: From Old French ussier 'doorkeeper.'
example: He ushered us into the theater.

definition: Walk with effort through water or another substance.
etymology: Old English wadan 'to go, advance.'
example: They waded through the stream.

definition: Utter a short, sharp cry.
etymology: From Old English gielpan 'to boast.'
example: The dog yelped in surprise.

definition: Amusingly unconventional and idiosyncratic.
etymology: From Italian zanni 'comic figure.'
example: He wore a zany costume to the party.
